bibl.title: Letter from Eugene R. Whitmore to Henry Rose Carter, November 23, 1917

div1.p: Whitmore requests Carter's opinion for a paper he is writing. Whitmore discusses Weil's Disease and its relation to yellow fever.

div1.head: Letter from Eugene R. Whitmore to Henry Rose Carter, November 23, 1917

opener.dateline:
ARMY MEDICAL SCHOOL
WASHINGTON, D. C.
November 23, 1917.

div1.p:
I am glad to have your letter of November 20. I am going to read my
paper on the mechanism of relapse in malaria at the Johns Hopkins Medical Society
meeting of December 3. I have been puttering on the thing since the summer of
1914, and, as it is in the nature of a “scientific” disease of childhood, I thought
it best to publsih what I have, and get ready to stick strictly to the man's work.
I do hope you will be back in Baltimore by that time, as I would like to see you
and I want to have you there to make any suggestions you care to. I will try to
get the paper in shape to send a copy of it tp you ahead of time, so you can look it
over and have time to think of loop holes in it. Also, they are going to give a
little dinner over there that night, and they want to have you there, if you are in
Baltimore.

I am wondering what Doctor Guiteras found about yellow fever along the
north coast of Venezuela this summer. I see by the Public Health Reports that
yellow fever was “present” in Venezuela in September. I have been thinking a lot
about those isolated cases and outbreaks of yellow fever, in which it is not possible
for anyone -- ancient savants or young fry -- to explain the origin, or even to
suggest it. And I believe that it would be well to study those cases with the idea
that some of them may be Weil's Disease (Infectious Jaundice). Of course, it would
be difficult to get the cases to study, as one usually learns of the case some weeks
or months after it is over. But a possible line, that might throw some light on the
question, would be to study the rats in such places, and determine whether many of
them are infected with the spirochete of infectious jaundice. I am very anxious to
get a chance to study the thing along some lines -- the Weil's Disease line being one
of them.

If I am not fortunate enough to have you at the meeting to criticise my idea on
relapse in malaria, I will hope to see you during the winter. I hope you will be
over to give some talks at the Hygienic Laboratory during the winter.

Really, I have nothing new about relapse in malaria, and all of the work that I
have done has been done before; but no one followed it out, and tried to correlate
the various bits of information in order to give a practical explanation of relapse.
But at that, I may be all wrong.
div1.closer: Yours very sincerely, Eugene R. Whitmore.
